document.text: Zealous for spiritual good of all. Even grieved if one brother fall.  Possessing a heart so noble and true. Proving what the weak I. H. N. can do. We wish the little paper could be in the hands of every invalid iu the country, it is such a comforting, cheering little sheet.,. Mrs. S. D. Saunders of Burke-, ville and Mr. C. Y. Hooper, of New Store, was visiting friends in this neighborhood last week. Farmers are already making preparations for another crop cleaning off their lands, filling up gullies, plowing whenever dry enough. One neighbor has planted his early irish potato crop, as the little Irishman says we bet you a button, our Times will be good in the hands of the new editors. Success to both. K.

document.text: YOUR best buys in school sup plies at Sneeds Pharmacy. Pursuant to authority vested in the undersigned Trustee by vir tue of that certain Deed of Trust dated July 15th, 1960, executed by R. L. Burke, Jr., of record on July 27th, 1960, in the Clerks Office of the Circuit Court of Ap pomattox County, Va., in D. B. 72, at Page 308, that whereas, default having been made in the payment of the indebtedness therein secured, and upon re quest by the holder of said obli gation that said Trust be execut ed, and in conformity therewith, the following real estate will be offered for sale in compliance with the terms and conditions of aforementioned instrument. Description Parcel No I All of that one-fourteenth 1- 14 undivided interest in the local dwelling house property, known as the R. F. Burke, Es tate,- located in the Town of Appomattox, Virginia, fronting on Railroad Street, bordering on Burke Street, adjoining the real estate of Mrs. W. R. Lizzie Reynolds, J. C. Cald well, Jr., et als and the C. S. Jenkins, estate Parcel No2 All of that one-half 1-2 un divided interest in the local dwelling house property of the late R. L. Burke, deceased, lo cated in the Town of Appo mattox, Virginia, fronting on Lee - Grant Avenue, contain ing 0.6597 of an acre, more or less, adjoining the real estate of Moses, formerly Mrs. Ethel F. Purdum on the Southeast, Wm. W.  Emily H. Burke on the Southwest and Northwest. Parcel No 2 is subject to a Prior Lien of 2,300.19, which includes interest to August 30th 1963. Place of Sale In Front of the Court House Time of Sale 1000 oclock a.m., August 30th., 1963 Terms of Sale Cash Auctioneer Percy W. George Trustee J. C. Davidson. 8-l-5t

document.text: Your 4-H Club -Rally will be held at Appomattox September 4th. The meeting will begin with a parade, starting ifrom the auditorium promptly at 1030. Every Club member is expected to attend, and make this parade as large and attractive as pos- siple. The County Agent and 4-H Club members of Prince Edward  have been invited to be with us. After the parade there will be a program in the auditorium songs, yells, and reports from each Club, district short course, and state short course. Mr. Montgomery, State Boys Club Agfent, and Mr. J. A. Burke, School Supt. will be the principle speakers. A picnic dinner will be spread on the grounds. The afternoon program will conclude Vesper Services then a picnic supper will be served, after which there will be games and stunts till 745. Moving pictures 8 p m., all club members will be charged admission fee of only ten cents. The public is cordially invited come, bring your friends and ask them to help you enjoy the day by bringing a basket of lunch. _

text.snippet: and Mr. J. A. <mark>Burke</mark>, School Supt. will be

highlights.snippet: and Mr. J. A. <mark>Burke</mark>, School Supt. will be

document.text: years ago I had a business transaction with The Fanners National Bank here which also involved a like trans action through The State Bank of Pamplin in which several hundred dollars was involved which after some reflection and checking up on my part I felt and was of the opinion that an error of several hundred dollars had been made against me and, requested Mr. Harwood, cashier of The Farm ers National Bank to investigate the m atter thoroughly going back . over his records and see if any error had been made. Mr. Harwood informs me that he has made careful and pains taking research regarding this transaction and assures ihe that the transaction was correct, which explanation I accept and hereby make public the fact that I am now satisfied with his explana tion and wish to make public apology for any statement which luj.taignjthave made which would E ffect on any one with regard to, this business transaction. J ohn W. W ebb . W itness R. L. Burke.

document.text: With the exception of Ivey Hol land, chairman of the Finance Committee, there are strong in dications that five out of the six Town Councilmen of Appomat tox will seek re - election. Holland last week stated em phatically that he will not seek election again. The others Mrs. Calvin Robinson, Burke Guill, Randolph Gilbert, Henry Pack, and Lewis McDearmon, are eith er uncommitteed at this time, or have stated that they are con sidering running again. Mayor Lawson Dr. S. R. Lawson, town mayor, says that a number of people have asked him to run again, and that he is seriously con sidering it.

Burke, J today urged all tax-payers to S see him and straighten up their  accounts immediately. He stat-  ed that he would be at his of-1 j fice in the Bank of Appomattox j through Saturday to receive f  taxes.  -A    p Payments have been very l satisfactory this week he re-  ported and the rush of the. next 1 two days is expected to bring 5  collections up to normal.

document.text: with Miss Mary Elizabeth Paris Mr. William Price with Miss Lucy Smith Mr. Tom Steele with Miss Maude Gregory. The ushers were Messrs. John Rolfe Horsley, B. Watkins Nowlin, John Overton and lampton Steele. The little ribbon- bearers were Jerry Burxe and Jao- queline Atwood Curtis Taylor and Fraces Abbitt Kendall Huuter and Katie Woolridge, and James Stanley and Mattie Sears. Before thp bridal party entered one verse of O Promise Me was softly-sung by Miss Eula Burke ac companied by Mrs. J. R. Atwood. At the conclusion of the solo follow ed the strains of Lohengrins wedding march. The bridesmaids entered from the left wing of tbe church near the altar and passed in front of the altar and down the right aisle. The male attendants entered the left aisle at the front of the church and marched down the right aisle while the bridesmaids passed up the left, forming a semi-circle around the al tar. Following the attendants the groom on the arm of the best man en tered the right aiale, while the bride on the arm of her father, Mr. H. F, Burke, appeared in the left aisle, and proceeded to the alter. The bride was preceded by the maid of honor and followed by her colored maid, Sarah. The bride was attired in a hand some traveling dress of broad-cloth with hat and gloves to matcl. She carried in her hand a small white bible and a white rose-bud. The maid of honor wore a gown of cream crepe cloth, with trimmings of pearls and chiffon, and carried in her hand a large bunch of white chrysanthemums. Tfie bridesmaids wore dresses of white silk mull wearing aigrettes in their hair, and each carrying a white rose iu her hand. After lunching at the brides home they happy pair left on the 130 oclock train for a tour through the West, followed by the best wishes of a host of friends. The groom is a son of Mr. John Steel, of Concord, and bolds the re sponsible position of Agent at Spout Springs of tbe N.  W. By., and is a young man highly esteemed and very popular wherever known. He  has for his young bride a daughter I of Mr. B. F. Burke, cashier of our bank. She is attractive popular, j and highly accomplished. She is  an expert at the telegraph key and Mr. Steele will have a help mate ca pable as be. The presents were  costly and beautiful.

Otis Sims spent last week end with his grandmother. -------- o------------ The fifth Sunday institute of the Appomattox circuit was That the Appomattox county School Board at its regular meeting at Appomattox, at of flee of Div. Supt., Wednesday, June 8, at 1000 A. M., will re ceive bids for a school bus to run from a point one mile be yond the present Bent Creek white schoolhouse, on Rt. 13, by Bent Creek to Oakville, on Route 306. The bus body must be a standard, closed top with a capacity from 25 to 85 chil dren. Contract to run for two years. The contractor is to pay two-thirds of cost of lia bility insurance. J. A. Burke, Snpt.

document.text: With deepest sorrow the Womans Club of Appomattox pays tribute to the memory of one of its Organ izing and Charter Members, Bessie V. Harwood Caldwell, whose death occured on June 24th, 1955 . Public spirited to a high degree she was an unfailing worker in all good causes. Over the years every progressive movement in Church and community has owed much to her support, for Bessie V. was a leader in educational, health, recreational, and civic activities. From early youth she was a faithful and devot ed member of Liberty Baptist Church, and was a pillar of strength in its organizations and Church life. We pay tribute to her life of in spiration and accomplishments. She was devoted to her children, family, and home always loyal to her friends true to her convictions strong in her Christian faith, and optimistic in her outlook. Even unto the end her thoughts and plans were in consideration of others. In spite of her progressing ill. ness she kept up with her usual in terests with a courageous spirit. In no greater way did she exemplify her bravery than in her efforts to seek and use every known means of medical treatment, not solely for the purpose of her own recovery but also that others similiarly strick en might be helped. Though she is gone, always in our midst is she because Love makes memory eternal. Mrs. Robert C. Hubbard Mrs. Joel W. Flood Mrs. Jerry A. Burke, Chairman Resolution Committee. October 3, 1955. ltc

document.text: With a goal of - 1,900, the lar gest quota the county has ever had, the Appomattox County Red Cress Chapter has completed plans for the War Fund Drive beginning on March 1 and continuing through out the month. Rev. H. Frederick Jofies, who Ser ved as chairman . of the drive for 1942, is again serving , M,the 1948 chairman. Members ox the commit tee who have joined in planning the drive with Mr. Jones ere Miss Eula May Burke, R. B. Hudgins, Chas. T. Moses, J. C. Rudgins, Geo. F. Abbitt, Sr., Mrs. H. P. Jones, and pastors of the churches in the county, together wltji a. number of farmers of the coujity,.  The publicity committee .eludes Calvin H. Robinson, chairman, Ma yor C. S. McDearmon, Appoiittox, Mayor N. E. Farrar, Pamplin, Judge J. W. Flood, and Mrs. H. F. ,Jones. Mrs. C. T. Moses is serving as chairman of the production - com mittee. Miss Jessalyn Hancock was made treasurer of this drive. Mrs. W. W, Burke is acting as secretary of the drive. j . Each person is asked to share in raising the county quota.

document.text: WINNERS OF THE CHAMPIONSHIP FLIGHT, Couples Captains Choice Golf, Tournament at Falling River Country Club Sunday were, from left, Jerry Conner, Ruby Roach, Becky Burke and Bill Burke. Team scored seven under par, 65, for 18 holes.
